Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope for Earth Science Research and Training of the Next Generation of Geoscientists
Award.AbstractNarration:
1551342
Moecher

In this proposal submitted to the EAR Instrumentation and Facilities Program, the PIs requested $149,947 to support acquisition of a scanning electron microscope (SEM) for grain-scale textural and chemical characterization of earth materials by faculty and students in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences at the University of Kentucky (UK). The requested SEM would support NSF/EAR funded research in petrotectonics and other fields. Specific studies would include investigations of mid-crustal transpression that require dating of deformed plutonic rocks via zircon U-Pb geochronology and dating monazite growth tied to deformation microstructures in metapelites within and bounding zones of transpression. Prior to U-Pb and monazite geochronologic techniques SEM imaging of zircons and monazites via SEM is required. Additional research includes studies of the petrogenesis of granites and sedimentary rocks, the latter with implications for hydrocarbon reservoir evaluation and for studies of the effects of CO2 injection on reservoir rock mineralogy and porosity evolution.

The requested SEM would support graduate and undergraduate student research training and local high school outreach efforts by the PI and benefit scientists at the on-campus branch of the Kentucky Geological Survey, where the instrument would be housed. This support is congruent with NSFs mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national welfare given the importance of student training opportunities in microanalysis technologies to support future scientific workforce needs and the advancement of research that may benefit future subsurface carbon dioxide sequestration efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Kentucky Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences (UK EES) and Kentucky Geological Survey (KGS) collaborated on the acquisition of a scanning electron microscope (SEM) for the purposes of expanding the range of analytical capabilities in earth science research, teaching/training, and public outreach. The PI (Moecher) supervises training, access to, and maintenance of the instrument. We encourage anyone and everyone to use the instrument, including the general public (see the wide range of users below).

 

Instrument capabilities include high spatial resolution imaging (~1 micron) using scanning electron (SE), backscattered electron (BSE), and cathodoluminescence (CL) detectors; qualitative and quantitative chemical analysis of solids via silicon drift detector, energy dispersive spectrometry, including light-element (C, N, O) detection; low-vacuum BSE imaging of materials that may be unstable in high vacuum; X-ray mapping capabilities; rapid, high precision stage motion using click-and-drag capabilities; and stage tilt for optimizing imaging.

 

One of the most impactful aspects of the new SEM is its ease of use. Anyone (faculty, students, staff, public) can be collecting images after 10 minutes of instruction. Failsafe design prevents users from unintentionally damaging the instrument. There is literally one click required to begin imaging mode once the sample is loaded. The high spatial resolution and ease of use have been critical for improving our analytical capabillities beyond the electron probe microanalyzer at UK, which is less flexible, yields lower image resolution, and requires a higher level of user training. 

 

Users of the instrument include the following:

 

1. UK faculty in the EES (Profs. Moecher, Freeman, Erhardt, McGlue), Anthropology (Prof. Pool), and Chemical-Materials Engineering (Balk) at UK, and/or their students (Moecher: 5 M.S., 1 Ph.D, 1 H.S.; Erhardt: 1 PhD., 1 post-doc, 2 M.S.; McGlue: 1 M.S., 1 Ph.D.; Pool: 1 Ph.D.).

 

2. Faculty from Eastern Kentucky University (Prof. S. Ferrar).

 

3. Staff Scientists of the KGS (Harris, Backus, Anderson, Parris)

 

Examples of research, teaching/training, and outreach activities include the following:

 

RESEARCH

 

1. Support of NSF-funded (Tectonics, Petrology & Geochemistry, Sedimentary Geology & Paleontology) research projects by Moecher (3 NSF awards) and McGlue (1 NSF award) that resulted in multiple abstracts/presentations of research at professional meetings (GSA Annual and Sectional meeting; AGU) and peer-reviewed publications.

 

2. Support of NSF-funded EHR GEO-PATHS grant (to Prof. Rebecca Freeman) that examined how high school students (Fayette County Public School System “STEAM” Academy magnet program) make decisions on college majors and careers. High school students were mentored by EES graduate students and were introduced to earth science research programs that incorporate scanning electron microscopy.

 

3. Support of industry-funded research projects that aim to enhance the productivity of oil and gas wells in black shales of the Permian basin, and suitability of carbonate reservoirs for produced water storage (Erhard, McGlue).

 

4. Support of KGS-funded research on unconventional “tight-sands” oil and gas production in the Berea sandstone play of eastern Kentucky and the Rogersville shale of central Kentucky.

 

5. Support of miscellaneous unfunded research projects including micropaleontology research on Cambro-Ordovician brachiopods (Freeman).

 

Complete compilations of research productivity may be accessed at the personal web pages of Profs. Earhardt, Freeman, McGlue and Moecher at https://ees.as.uky.edu/faculty.

 

TEACHING/TRAINING – UK courses that incorporate the SEM into the curriculum include (with instructor)

 

1. EES 360 Mineralogy for baccalaureate majors (Dr. K. Ratajeski) – two labs on microanalysis.

2. EES 645 Petrotectonics for graduate students (Prof. Moecher) – completion of a research project involving geothermobarometry.

 

OUTREACH

 

1. Four high school teachers in two local school systems participated in one of the goals, which was to expand access to scientific instrumentation use of the SEM’s remote communication and operation capabilities.

 

2. The instrument is showcased via demonstrations to the public (primarily K-12 students and their parents) during the annual National Earth Science Week open house jointly hosted by the KGS and EES.

 

3. Members of the Bluegrass Gem and Mineral Club use the instrument to analyze potential new minerals.

 

4. High school student interns supported by the GEO PATHS grant and visiting students from India supported by a U.S. State Department grant completed hands-on activities using the SEM.

 

5. A student from Dunbar High School in Lexington completed her "360 Hour" research project required for the STEM magnet program. The student conducted a detrital zircon U-Pb provenance study as part of Moecher's active NSF grant on sedimentary recycling. This included all aspects of zircon analysis including BSE and CL imaging of hundreds of zircons before and after LA-ICP-MS U-Pb geochronology at the University of Arizona. 

 

DIVERSTIY

 

Two female faculty, 7 female graduate students, one female high school student, and one African American graduate student became proficient independent users of the SEM.
